reviews.review_text: Good game, but the intermediate to advanced levels and achievements are quite tough unless you're a regular Magic player. Deckbuilding is kind of a bear (some things are just easier in real life), and I take issue with how the rules for some of the card powers were interpreted. All in all a solid Magic computer game, with a reasonably tough AI for non-veteran players.

Magic 2013 was... underwhelming. While I appreciate all the new cards that were added, the experience as a whole felt less interesting than Magic 2012  Fortunately I was able to unlock cards this time around. Given the sheer number of decks, they really should have awarded at least two cards per battle. 30 battles per deck is just a horrible time sink, especially when it's not as fun as it used to be. I'm also starting to wish they had an option to turn off ALL animations. If I'm going to be grinding a long-♥♥♥ game, I don't want to see every card taking 5-10 seconds to play.  Sadly Archenemy mode is gone, and 2-headed giant only exists in custom games. I actually found both of those fun. In its place is Planechase mode which... *shudder*. Every round you wait for 3 CPUs to take their turns and they spin that atrocious dice over and over again. It's just... kill me now. Every time.  To the game's credit, decks felt more balanced overall. There's some strategy involved where some decks fare much better versus others, instead of a one-size-fits-all deck, but I kind of miss the feeling of overpoweredness from the previous game. The puzzles are still fun too.  Overall it's a distinctly inferior game compared to 2012. On its own, only average. I'll rate it 6/10. It makes me wish I was playing the last one.

The special edition unlocks every card for each deck (including foil), but you have to unlock the extra cards on the standard version by battling the single player AI. There are various single player modes and multiplayer modes. There is some degree of deck customization but you cannot have less than 60 cards per deck, and you cannot remove standard land cards.  pros: addictive gameplay, includes a tutorial for newer players, good soundtrack, and visuals cons: clunky menu, clunky UI, needs more deck customization, multiplayer browser needs improvement  For all the Magic fans, this is worth trying out. A free demo is available if you are undecided.

having played this game before on ps3 i knew what i was buying for those who do not... m:tg dotp2013 is the 3rd instalment in the dotp series the second install ment included  single player campaign  multiplayer duels 2headed giant : two teams of two players  and Archenemy (a magic variation 1 vs 3) dotp 2013 includes single player campaign  multiplayer duels 2headed giant : two teams of two players  and Planechase ( a two to four player magic variant)  in planechase you and each other player shar the control of the planechase deck which has the top card reveiled at all times. any rule changes the plane chase card says is THE RULE if all creatures get -5 to their attack and the creeature is normally a 6/6 then you now have a 1/6. planechase also features a six sided die called the planar die one side has the planeswalker symbol and the opposite side features the chaos symbol the remaining four sides are left intentionally blank to signify the dificulty in pulling the true power of the plan(the chaos symbol) or the strength of power necessary to switch planes (the planswalker symbol)  the two types on planechase cards are phenomenon = when you plip a phenomenon card face up it happens immediatly then you flip the next card face up. phenomenon in clude things like draw 4 cards or each non planeswalk roll of the die is chaos  planes = these cards feature some of the know planes of the mtg multiverse and some of the prominent locations of these planes. each plane card has a static ability... usually a when or if function  example:  you may cast enchantments as if they had flash if you roll the chaos symbol: destroy target creature that is not enchanted  the decks in this version of mtg are premade and you can unlock cards to modify each deck with by winning with that deck either versus the ai or people.  graphics... 7/10 the game is a card game so graphics are not too necessary but the art work may have you pausing to look often gameplay: 4/10 each time something new shows up the game will tell you whats going on there is also the ability to zoom in on each card and select the option to tell you what each ability means but in no ways can you say this game will baby you if you wanna play soley agains the ai thats fine but the real point of this is to play multiplayer... you know with other people. and at the time of writing this review i would have to say that there is no multiplayer unless you know a guy(or girl) that also has this game and wants to play with you.  overall: 8/10 high replayability fans of mtg will always come back and play a round or two with people they know and the mear strategy involved in just this small of a card pool is still enough for anyone

This game is great for learning how to play Magic, which is why I got it. The main problem with this game is that the save function is glitched and only saves the previous match but not the one that you just finished, and the company behind the game doesn't give a damn. This game is well made, but at its core, it is still a cash-in by Wizards of the Coast. Buy this game if you have friends to play with, or if you just really enjoy Magic enough that you don't mind your game not always saving. For the most part, I don't feel that I can positively recommend a game that its own company doesn't care enough about to make sure the save feature works properly.

Eh. I'm not a huge fan of playing MtG through the computer. There's something about shuffling the cards, the smell of the cards, and the physicality of playing across from someone (or a group of people...EDH anyone?). The game itself is not bad, but it's not for me. There were also times when I wanted to do a complex trick in a game, and either the game couldn't accomodate the trick (even though it was within the rules of magic), or I couldn't figure out how to do it within the game mechanics. I actually lost a few matches that way.  I'd say it's a pass, unless you want to learn how to play - then it's pretty good!

I bought the Gold Game Bundle of this game. I played the card game as a kid many years ago and loved it, and also really enjoyed playing this digital version now. The problem is that whenever I unlock a card and then exit the game, the card is locked again when I come back to play later. I did some research and it seems to be a pretty common issue for some people that's been around since release with no known real solution - at least not that I could find. Considering the fact that the whole purpose of the single player portion of the game is to defeat opponents to unlock cards, I obviously can't recommend the game and would advise that people not waste their time unless they plan on buying all of the unlocks with cash to play multiplayer.
